prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB x B_ -> 4/4 B_
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG x BG -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BG, 1/4 GG
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue

data.expected: BT x BT -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 BT, 1/4 TT

:
BB x G_ -> 1/4 BB, 1/2 G_, 1/4 T_
If you look at the table of dominant/recessive/surrounnding traits, you can see that the off-white coat color of the dogs is determined by a single gene that is dominant to the other allele. Therefore, if the parents both have the dominant allele (for example, "A" for "A" for white), each of their offspring will have a 25% chance of inheriting a gray coat. If one parent has a dominant allele (for example, "A" for white) and the other has a recessive allele (for example, "a" for gray), each of their offspring will have a 50% chance of inheriting the gray coat, but also a 25% chance of inheriting the dominant coat color, which is the mix of the dominant gene and the gray gene (for example, "A" for white with the dominant allele "a" for gray, resulting in a gray coat with white patches). If one parent has the recessive allele (for example, "a" for gray) and the other has the dominant allele, each of the offspring will have a half chance of inheriting the gray coat and a half chance of not inheriting the gray coat, resulting in a mix of the dominant and recessive genes that is unique to each individual. The possible alleles for this gene are A and a (genotypes GA, AA, and G_A).<|im_end|>
